Dear DT of NY & DK of LA,

I guess I wasn't clear.  The day in question had been developing for over a month: friends arriving from Philadelphia, a needed dentist appointment, chemo therapy for the old dog, dinner with wife and sons.  These dates do not change just because the sprinkler guys show up at the last minute or the door is suddenly delivered.  

Family, teeth, psyche and pooch need occasional TLC too. One day a month doesn't seem indulgent. One's responsibilities extend beyond the four walls of a business.

You chose a day in the city to run errands instead over being onsite to supervise a crucial day of installation?  You deserve exactly what you got.  I understand a day off to take care of personal business, but not when there's a perfect storm of mistakes brewing by having three tradesmen come in on the same day to do final installation work.  Get your priorities back in line and realize your personal life is second to this business at all times until you get it open and operating.  So much money wasted by not paying attention...

I don't run a business, but as an avid Twitter user, I'd like to echo some of the criticisms here....

Social media will only benefit a business if the business uses it to generate something that people want. Even if a user likes a particular company and often makes purchases from them, why should they clutter up their online feeds with posts unless they get something useful? I feel as though if a company wants to launch a social networking campaign, they need to compartmentalize some sort of gimmick, game, story, or exclusive deals for people who are "following" them on a given social media stream. Otherwise, you're just asking for people to willingly accept more advertising in their lives that they will learn to ignore.

A few weeks back, a temp firm I once worked for sent me a Friend request on Facebook. Looking at their Facebook page immediately told me that they jumped on the social media bandwagon without actually considering what it would do for them (which is unfortunate, because a national temp. agency could benefit a great deal from social media).

The same thing happened when blogs were all the rage a few years back. NBC would boast that you could read your favorite characters' blogs on the NBC website. But then the blogs weren't very funny and didn't provide enough interesting content to keep the reader going back to it each week, or month.

Half-hearted attempts to commercialize on the newest internet fads don't generate business, they generate useless text.

Hmmm... I think I will go to Lowes Home Improvement Centers and buy a 4x8 sheet of white laminate board for $11 or $12. (Probably $45 in Manhattan, but hey!). Somehow that seems more price effective, and an effective antidote to sticker shock, than even this gee-whiz globe-trotting solution.
But this solution did get the press, whereas the hum-drum 4x8 sheet of stuff at Lowes just sits there in an unassuming way.

Sandra Lee's recipe with all its excessive sodium and whatever else is in that canned soup is an abomination. Call it what you like, but don't call that lasagne. This is what lazy, ignorant people make.

If you want real lasagne, make it some weekend day with fresh ingredients and then freeze it for later when you need an emergency meal. Feed your family real FOOD!

It gives me great hope that people have such strong feelings about a lasagna.  As a professional cook determined to stir passion in people for making their own food and eating around a table I LOVE to hear that Ms. Cuomo is stating her case.  As for a lasagna made with cottage cheese--it can only make it worse.

I am an Italian-American wife married to an Eastern European husband.  When my Slovakian mother-in-law served us her spaghetti sauce made with condensed tomato soup, I made it clear that if Italian food was to be cooked, I would cook it.  My Italian grandmother's spaghetti sauce, which was the basis of her lasagna, is simple.  It includes basil, parsley, onion, and garlic but absolutely never oregano, green pepper, or bay leaves.  No wine in the sauce and Parmesan was added to the pasta with the sauce.  Grandma  would be rolling over in her grave at the very thought of tomato soup and vinegar in lasagna or spaghetti sauce!

Let me get this straight: Wall Street robber barons can run the economy totally off the rails and walk away with multimillion-dollar bonuses, and both state AND federal regulations prohibit "cheese counter" employees from pocketing tips?

Maybe the Tea Partiers are onto something, after all ...

Cook's Illustrated had the idea of using cottage cheese in place of ricotta so that one could make a lasagna ahead of time and freeze it for up to a month. Which is why mega food conglomerates do the same. SL's recipe, what it lacks in originality, more than makes up for it in a complete lack of taste.

I hope SL's recipe at least demands that one recycles the cans since that would be the only redeeming thing about her "food." If her goal is just to stuff calories down one's throat (which would be understandable considering her claim to a childhood of poverty) then she has truly hit the mark.

I find it strangely odd that she spends as much time on her show designing her freaksihly strange themed tablescapes and cocktails as she does to create a half dozen different dishes. If she were to put even half that energy into finding something as simple as a better version of tomato soup than Campbell's (hey, try Trader Joe's tomato soup in a box!) she might actually produce something that approaches the minimum level of palatability acceptable to even the least discerning of palates.

Sandra Lee is crying all the way to the bank, and that's what really bothers those who feel so superior to her!  I hate to think of the abuse she's going to take during A. Cuomo's campaign.  Give her a break.

As an regular "single" male with my wife on the road much of the time, REAL cooking is a pleasure. The garbage that Sandra Lee "creates" as a service to her paymasters is a bloody nightmare! Her so-called recipes are just another reason Americans are turning so unhealthy and obese. We are now the laughingstock of the world.

We have to go back to making our foods from scratch. If we don't spend the time on creating real and what can be categorized as "traditional" foods using traditional methods, we will continue the decline in our overall food standards.

I have given up watching the Food Network. It is a poor and now miserable excuse for a cable channel. I hate to say to it but it was vastly superior back when Emeril ruled the roost! At least his food was healthy and interesting.

Sandra Lee, go back to school, please and stop foisting your paid advertisements on us. I am sorry to say that with what you are you are no better than a high priced prostitute.

When we moved to North Carolina in the mid-80's, Kroger's had Ronzoni spaghetti in the "international foods" aisle, along with Chun King fried noodles. Ricotta? They'd never heard of it. That's why Sandra's "old family recipe" subbed cottage cheese. And - now, all y'all New Yorkers sit down and take a deep breath - there are still places in the country where one can't get ricotta.

Give the woman a break. Her niche isn't the one occupied by Julia or even Martha. I'm not a fan of her recipes, but they are still preferable to the over-wrought and oh-so-precious dishes concocted by some other cookbook writers.
Beets, a little lemon, sour cream. Add dill if you like. Summer borscht -- cold, sweet, tangy, refreshing. And it'll be hot pink! (Straight up sweet beet would probably be good, too.)

# 9 Mike Roddy

Dear Mike,

Regarding your assertion that "Having worked with engineers most of my life, it's become evident that the worst ones are those who work in mature industries, such as the oil industry";

My first thought was an indignant quote from Groucho Marx, along the lines of "I resemble that remark!"

My second thought was "Mike may have worked with engineers most of his life, but he has just proved that he has never worked with oil and gas industry engineers. Otherwise he would never write something so ill-informed."

To dismiss the oil and gas industry cavalierly as a "mature" industry is so simplistic as to be much more wrong than right.

Oil and gas is a mature MARKET. But the industry itself has many facets, some of which have no equal in technological sophistication.

Some of the smaller parts of it (production from rod-pumped stripper wells) are indeed fairly described as "mature" technology.

But the largest frontier fields use pioneering exploration and production methods with enormously exciting cutting-edge technology.

The oil and gas industry geologists and petroleum engineers produce 3-dimensional seismic maps of the earth's crust up to 8 miles deep, to a vertical resolution of 5 feet, using Cray supercomputers. They are finding hydrocarbons in granite, which was thought impossible only 10 years ago. Do you really believe their thinking is "invariably derivative"?

The revolution in shale gas, which just might be the low-carbon salvation of this entire nation, required two enabling technolgies; 1) high pressure fracturing to split low-permeability shale, and 2) the ability to slant drill up to a mile away from the vertical with precision.

These technologies were developed by lean, hungry independent oil and gas companies like Oklahoma-based Devon Energy, Chesapeake and Anadarko.

Think a minute as to how you would go about controlling the drill bit on a well that has gone three miles down and one mile horizontal with enough precision to hit a "pay zone" no wider than 30 feet.

It was not an "invariably derivative" thinker who worked that one out.

Think about what makes it possible to even contemplate drilling or producing hydrocarbons in 5000 or 7000 feet of water? These are not "mature" technologies; they are newer and more innovative than space travel (consider: the Space Shuttle is 1970's technology. The ill-fated Deepwate Horizon was 30 years more modern in every way technology counts)

I personally have seen many marvels of great engineering in alternative fuels, better batteries, waste heat recovery and novel chemistry come out of oil companies. The ONLY renewable liquid fuel with any hope of commercialization is biodiesel from algae, which is bank-rolled to the tune of many hundreds of millions of $$ by Exxon-Mobil.

It is certainly true that many of the best engineering innovations in the oil and gas industry come from hungry independents. Indeed, Apache is one of the world leaders in deepwater drilling. Like large organizations of all sorts, big oil companies get sluggish precisely because they are big.

But take a look at the patent count coming out of the oil industry compared to others. In 2008 Schlumberger and ExxonMobil both filed for over 250 patents each. This puts them ahead of high tech heavy hitters like Monsanto, Samsung, Merck and Pfizer.

In 2008 Shell had a slow year for patents, "only" 135. But this put them ahead of Raytheon, Daimler-Benz, Rolls-Royce, Stanford U and MIT.

So I believe the assertion that oil and gas industry engineers are among the worst engineers, "invariably derivative" and that "few engineers in any field are creative to begin with" cannot be supported by the facts on the ground.

By the way, I fully support the idea of a 3rd party investigation of the sunken Deepwater Horizon. It should happen, and when it does, it will use ingenious ROV's and high-tech inspection devices already widely deployed on the world's deepwater oil and gas drilling rigs.

If you retort, "If those oil and gas engineers are so smart, why did the BP Macondo well blow out?" I think the answers are starting to come out of the various investigations on this incident. I emphasize that I speak for no one but myself here, and it is only my own untutored opinion which follows.

But my opinion is that, when all the facts are known and all the investigations are completed, well, (how shall I say this delicately?)...BP's reputation for technical competence will not be enhanced. Quite the contrary.
I try not to be too cynical but can't help wondering: Is Tony Hayward one of the small people Svanberg was referring to? He looks pretty small - shorter than anyone else in the video, certainly.

Clearly, in the rush of events, the right wing echo chamber's focus group testing of memes is playing catch up here.

The fact is, Barton was simply echoing one of the chamber's trial balloon talking point--to wit that the BP/White House agreement was really just that bare-knuckled "Chicago politics" they keep talking about.

What is really revealing in all of this is that it makes clear that the echo chamber has gotten so accustomed to talking at--and hearing their blather bounce back resoundingly--to the angry base--they are almost completely tone deaf to how this pity-pot whining for the private sector is playing outside the bubbleheads in the base.

Just when I thought it couldn't get any worse for the teabaggin' repubs...BAM!! But it could not be helped, the way they were heading, either hit a wall or drive it into a ditch. C'mon, gimme your hand, I'll help you out of your hole....umm, NOT!

Unfortunately, there are many like Joe Barton in this country who feel unfettered industry is the end all and be all of democracy; Their model of society conforms to the old feudal system whereby the corporate sector provides us with wages while we the serfs provide our labor for their enterprises. Rights and benefits are just a construct of those socialists on the left.

What Joe Barton said is disgusting; nonetheless, he said what the rest of the GOP believes in but will not say in public because they need to manipulate the masses of asses with the smoke and mirror show of abortion and religion. Anyone who does not see the handwriting on the wall and realizes that our future has been sold to the oil companies for a few thousand dollars in "campaign donations" which constitute the real shakedown of our society is either blind or works for big oil.
Seersucker suits? Prison stripes would be more appropriate for almost all in Congress.
Another brainless Republican who reminds us why the GOP is the minority party and will remain such until they get some education!

I think it is clear from the Republicans side of the aisle and particularly this Republican, that "small people" mean nothing to them. But, it is the "small people" who are suffering from the giant oil spill of the big corporations that are so willing to hand millions in campaign contributions to those in Washington who will look the other way at regulating their industry.
Then, there are the representatives in Washington who are for the "small people" and want to be assured that at least $20 billion is paid by BP so they don't take an easy out by claiming bankruptcy. That's not a slush fund - it is an escrow fund. Idiots who don't know the difference have no business sitting in the seats of the House of Representatives.

"Against Gov. Jindal's Wishes, Crude-Sucking Barges Stopped by Coast Guard"

with help like this, the federal government would serve its citizens better by staying out of

this crisis.

Rep. Joe (former executive of an oil company that owns 25% of Deep Water) Barton really meant to say was we are a nation of laws. And one law that I helped draft, was to limit oil company liability to $75 million max. BP should just ignore the President because the GO-BP has you covered by a great law.
Hopefully, Jindal will suspend his "General Patton" portrayal while meeting with Kenneth Feinberg.
